page.title: 05Blean Woods N.C.C.
page.content: Blean Woods National Nature Reserve is part of the ancient Royal Forest of Blean and covers 66.5 hectares. It has conserved a typical example of the ancient woods being chestnut coppice with broadleafed standards on largely acid soil, over London Clay, with abundant insect life and unusual plants. This is one of the few remaining sites in England where the Heath Fritillary butterfly can be found. Being close to the coast the woods offer a convenient stopping point for many continental species of invertebrates. On part of the reserve traditional coppicing encourages flora including woodrush,butchers broom.The remainder is being brought back to high forest of native trees and shrubs. Open rides and paths simulate open glades encouraging different species.
